extracted-table.table-caption: Participant characteristics in the Framingham Heart Study.
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test.; IQR, interquartile range; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NP, neuropsychological evaluation; PSMD, peak width of skeletonized mean diffusivity; SD, standard deviation; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; TMT, Trail Making Test; WHR, waist‐to‐hip ratio; WMH, white matter hyperintensity.aPrevalent cardiovascular disease includes history of transient ischemic attack, coronary heart disease, congestive heart failure, or peripheral vascular disease.

caption.p: Participant characteristics in the Framingham Heart Study.

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test.; IQR, interquartile range; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NP, neuropsychological evaluation; PSMD, peak width of skeletonized mean diffusivity; SD, standard deviation; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; TMT, Trail Making Test; WHR, waist‐to‐hip ratio; WMH, white matter hyperintensity.
Prevalent cardiovascular disease includes history of transient ischemic attack, coronary heart disease, congestive heart failure, or peripheral vascular disease.

extracted-table.table-caption: Associations of leptin markers with neuropsychological test scores (n = 2262).
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note: Results from linear regression models with the respective neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor. Models are adjusted for age, sex, education, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and neuropsychological assessment. Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and raw p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings after false discovery rate control at 5% using the Benjamini‐Hochberg procedure are indicated in bold.Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test.;sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; TMT, Trail Making Test.aThese variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.bScores were multiplied by −1 so that higher scores reflect better cognitive performance.

caption.p: Associations of leptin markers with neuropsychological test scores (n = 2262).

fn.p: Note: Results from linear regression models with the respective neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor. Models are adjusted for age, sex, education, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and neuropsychological assessment. Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and raw p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings after false discovery rate control at 5% using the Benjamini‐Hochberg procedure are indicated in bold.
Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test.;sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; TMT, Trail Making Test.
These variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.
Scores were multiplied by −1 so that higher scores reflect better cognitive performance.

extracted-table.table-caption: Associations of leptin markers with MRI markers of brain atrophy and vascular injury (n = 2028).
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note: Results from linear regression models with the respective MRI marker as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor. Models are adjusted for age, sex, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition. Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and raw p values (p). Statistically significant findings after false discovery rate control at 5% using the Benjamini‐Hochberg procedure are indicated in bold.Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index, MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; PSMD, peak width of skeletonized mean diffusivity.; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; WMH, white matter hyperintensity.aThese variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.bas percentage of total cranial volume.cModels are further adjusted for total cranial volume.

caption.p: Associations of leptin markers with MRI markers of brain atrophy and vascular injury (n = 2028).

fn.p: Note: Results from linear regression models with the respective MRI marker as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor. Models are adjusted for age, sex, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition. Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and raw p values (p). Statistically significant findings after false discovery rate control at 5% using the Benjamini‐Hochberg procedure are indicated in bold.
Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index, MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; PSMD, peak width of skeletonized mean diffusivity.; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; WMH, white matter hyperintensity.
These variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.
as percentage of total cranial volume.
Models are further adjusted for total cranial volume.

extracted-table.table-caption: Associations of leptin markers with MRI and cognitive outcomes in different sex subgroups.
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note: Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings at p ≤0.05 are indicated in bold.Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor.aLinear regression models with the respective MRI marker or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker, sex, as well as their product term as the main predictors. Values represent the p‐value of the respective product term (p for interaction). Only significant findings at p ≤0.1 are presented.bLinear regression models with the respective MRI marker or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor, conducted by sex subgroups.cModels are adjusted for age, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition.das percentage of total cranial volume.eThese variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.fModels are adjusted for age, education, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and neuropsychological assessment.gScores were multiplied by ‐1 so that higher scores reflect better cognitive performance.

caption.p: Associations of leptin markers with MRI and cognitive outcomes in different sex subgroups.

fn.p: Note: Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings at p ≤0.05 are indicated in bold.
Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor.

Linear regression models with the respective MRI marker or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker, sex, as well as their product term as the main predictors. Values represent the p‐value of the respective product term (p for interaction). Only significant findings at p ≤0.1 are presented.
Linear regression models with the respective MRI marker or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor, conducted by sex subgroups.

Models are adjusted for age, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition.
as percentage of total cranial volume.
These variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.

Models are adjusted for age, education, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and neuropsychological assessment.
Scores were multiplied by ‐1 so that higher scores reflect better cognitive performance.

extracted-table.table-caption: Associations of leptin markers with MRI and cognitive outcomes in different WHR subgroups.
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Note: Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings at p ≤0.05 are indicated in bold.Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; WHR, waist‐to‐hip ratio; WMH, white matter hyperintensity volume.aLinear regression models with the respective MRI measure or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker, WHR, as well as their product term as the main predictors. Values represent the p‐value of the respective product term (p for interaction). Only significant findings at p ≤ 0.1 are presented.bLinear regression models with the respective MRI measure or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor, conducted in different WHR subgroups.cModels are adjusted for age, sex, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition.dThese variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.eModels are further adjusted for total cranial volume.

caption.p: Associations of leptin markers with MRI and cognitive outcomes in different WHR subgroups.

fn.p: Note: Values represent beta coefficients (β), and their corresponding standard errors (SE) and p‐values (p). Statistically significant findings at p ≤0.05 are indicated in bold.

Abbreviations: FLI, free leptin index; HVOT, Hooper Visual Organization Test; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; sOB‐R, soluble leptin receptor; WHR, waist‐to‐hip ratio; WMH, white matter hyperintensity volume.

Linear regression models with the respective MRI measure or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker, WHR, as well as their product term as the main predictors. Values represent the p‐value of the respective product term (p for interaction). Only significant findings at p ≤ 0.1 are presented.
Linear regression models with the respective MRI measure or neuropsychological test score as the outcome and the respective leptin marker as the main predictor, conducted in different WHR subgroups.

cModels are adjusted for age, sex, diabetes mellitus, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, antihypertensive medication use, current smoking, prevalent cardiovascular disease, and time interval between blood draw and MRI acquisition.
These variables have been natural log‐transformed to normalize their distributions.
Models are further adjusted for total cranial volume.
